string.text: The village of Lagshofn on the downs of western Beinland was founded only two generations ago by the trader and explorer Lag, who cast his seat-pillars into the sea and followed them to this spot. It uses nearby tidal flats to harvest salt from the western oceans.

Chornad sits overlooking a pass through the Biscan hills. The villagers of this region, like many in the central Vlandian kingdom, specializing in raising pigs on the plentiful acorns that fall from the region's oak trees.
Tor Melina sits in a valley in the forested hills of the northwestern Uchalion massif. The south-facing slopes, well-drained and exposed to the sun, produce a fine crop of wheat.
Hanekhy sits atop a northern spur of the Akkan hills. Each day, the villagers climb down winding paths to tend their wheatfields in the plains below.

Hakarshus was the first settlement on the western coast of Beinland. Its founder, Hakar, harbored a resentment towards authority that was fierce even by local standards. His descendants have become whalers, venturing to the far north, away from kings and jarls and taxes, in search of their quarry.

Varagos sits on the Aris river, a small highland stream that flows into the deep pool known as the Ophthys. Landowners here have planted mulberry bushes on the warm hillsides, on which they cultivate silkworms.

Ostrif sits on a plateau on the eastern end of the Byalic Sea. Although the village lies somewhat inland, the inhabitants work as whalers, often doing specialized tasks like harpooning and carpentry on ships owned by residents of other regions.
Hertogea lies in the shadow of Mount Erithrys, a huge basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. Villagers grow olives on the slopes leading up the mountain.

Lovaheit was settled on a highland heath only two generations ago, as increased population in the Jumne valley pushed younger sons to sell their share of their inheritance and push into new territories. Even though the land was at first considered marginal, it now produces a fine crop of wheat.

The clifftop village of Skarthness is known for its intrepid hunters. While most of their neighbors are content to fish nearby banks, Skarthnessers voyage seasonally to the far north of Beinland on walrus hunts, bringing back valuable ivory.
Vinela sits beneath the waterfalls where the Aminys river rushes down to join the Perassic Sea. Early morning sea-mists from the west and the hot sun of midday allow the growing of wine grapes.

Erzenur sits alongside the Tiagys river, known in the local dialect as the Teyagh. The waters here have a distinct reddish tint from the iron in the soil, which the villagers mine from riverside outcrops.

Nifdal is named for the gloomy mists that climb up the slopes from the Jumne valley. The villagers here mine salt from deposits in the hills, and journey eastward in late summer to gather it from seasonally dry lakes in the steppeland beyond.
Ataconia sits on a plateau in the piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. The hills, rich with oak trees, are ideal for the raising of acorn-eating swine.
Korsyas sits near the narrowest part of the Bay of Varcheg. Villagers here specialize in hunting blackfish, minke and other smaller whales that breed in the bay.

Dorstrand overlooks the gravel beaches of the grim northwestern ocean. Villagers earn their living by fishing cod, char and other arctic fish, including a variety of deepwater sharks whose flesh must be fermented before it is eaten.

Meroc overlooks a cove in the Biscan Coast. Like many villages in this region, its inhabitants fish nearby banks for mullet and cod for their day-to-day meals, while its bolder seafarers go much further afield to hunt more lucrative quarry, in particular whales.

The villagers of Troverag fish the eastern Byalic Sea, where the runoff from the streams creates a brackish mix of saltwater and fresh. Here the catch consists of salmon, sea-trout and bottom-dwelling fish like flounder, caught in wicker traps.

The seafaring village of Tharklif lies at the foot of a cliff overlooking the Byalic Sea. The inhabitants fish local stocks of char and cod, but are most known for their long-ranging voyages in pursuit of right whales and bowheads which migrate through these waters.

The villagers of Kvol include the descendants of refugees and malcontents from across Calradia, seeking isolation in the cold northern forests. They grow barley for sustenance, but many far afield for seasonal work. Some join Nords and others on their walrus hunts in the far north.

Carphenion lies in the wooded highlands between the great basalt slab of Mount Erithrys and the Dryatic mountains. On summer nights the hills above the village are dotted with the fires of cattle herders, taking their animals to graze on the upland pastures.

Kjarved lies in the inland valleys of the western Nordvyg. Villagers tell stories of their famously foul-tempered and miserly ancestor Kjar, who came inland from the sea to escape a blood feud. For 60 years he mined salt from nearby deposits and accumulated a fabulous trove of wealth, all of which was a huge surprise to his dozens of children and grandchildren when they entered his modest farmhouse after his death to claim their inheritance.

Grud was a thegn of the jarl of Hargard who established an outpost on the Jumne river, which takes its name from the mysterious burial pits from some bygone people that lined its banks. The village named after him now raises sheep in pastures beside the river.

Fimbulgard was named for the beach-side shacks used to dry herring, the staple food of its seafaring inhabitants. The wealth of the village, however, comes from the seasonal voyages along the northern coasts in search of whales and their oil.

Zestea sits where the plains of Lycarea meet the coastal Iltaric hills. The people of this area are skilled at building weirs on the small streams rushing down the slopes, trapping trout and other fish.

Mjallagdal is one of several clifftop hamlets that overlooks the bay of Fimbulgard. Each morning, its residents make their way down the escarpment to fish the rich banks in the shallow waters offshore.
Hongard sits in the warm wooded lands near the meandering Trand river. This region, rich in wheat and once the heartland of the Empire, is now the center of the Vlandian kingdom.
Urunjan sits near the western edge of the Devseg plateau, at the foot of the Akkan hills. Villagers raise cattle here that are bred to withstand both the hot summers and freezing winters.
The village of Esme and its surrounding hamlets lie on the landward side of the Akkan hills on the Devseg plateau, prime grazing lands for the horses of the Khuzaits and their confederates.

Vagnafit lies in a basin under the hills known as the Kjolfjallen, from their resemblance to the keel of a ship. The once boggy depression was drained under the orders of King Volbjorn, and the land distributed to some of the veterans who helped him gain power to grow wheat for Thronderlag and other towns.
Gamardan sits at the head of a small bay that branches off the larger Gulf of Charas. The wines of this region are unusually sweet and strong, and valued throughout the Empire.
Ransam lies in the southeastern plains of the Devseg plateau. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, specialize in the rearing of horses.

Svinstak lies inland of the Nordvyg coast, separated from the sea by a row of sharp-ridged hills. Stands of old-growth oak and other trees are still common here, providing the north with much of the timber for its ships.

Bjorenbyr overlooks the straits between Beinland and the mainland, a site which allows its seafaring residents to hunt right whales, blackfish and other quarry on their migration routes between the Byalic Sea and the northern ocean.

Hoeksten is named after a mysterious monolith found in the fields here by wandering herdsmen, subsequently ordered dug up by the local jarl and used in the foundations of Ykerslund Castle. He also ordered a village built on the auspicious site to settle refugees who had fled from the wars of Nord unification on the coast, and provided them with herds of cattle.

Most months of the year, the residents of Dagby grow subsistence crops and fish the bay of Fimbulgard. But in the summer, they journey to the north, to the far coast of Beinland and beyond, to hunt walruses for their ivory.
Ravikayr sits on rich volcanic soil in the interior of Beinland. Here, on the lower slopes of the dark Oskfjal mountain, much of the island's supply of grain is grown.

The village of Agilting, straddling the plateau between the Byalic Sea and the Jumne river, began as a gathering point for local fishers and herders to resolve their claims and feuds. Like many such sites in the north, it has evolved into a village as local populations grew.

Jalskveg, in the east of the Nordvyg north of Thronderlag, lies on one of the main routes from the coast to the more sparsely populated interior. The area is thick with ancient oak trees, which are harvested and dragged to the coast by oxen for use in shipbuilding.

Ortongard sits in the center of the Devseg plateau, which is dry for most of the year but offers rich grazing in the spring. Founded by Darshi-speaking merchants, it made its wealth buying horses, sheep and cattle from the surrounding herding villages and sending them west to the markets of the empire in huge drives, accompanied by guards to ward off raiders from the steppes. Neither its walls nor its mercenary armies could withstand the coming of Khan Urkhun, however, who it granted to the Khergit clan in recognition of their valor.

Sirindac lies beneath the high ridges of the Ebor peninsula, somewhat sheltered from the bitter winds blowing out of the northwest. It was settled by prospectors hunting for silver in the mountain streams, but that has mostly been exhausted and the region now mostly exports clay for local potters.

Drapand sits near the tip of Cape Fal, a promontory just south of the mouth of the Trand River. The villagers venture out far into the seas to hunt right and blackfish whales, and sometimes range as far north as Beinland chasing bowheads and narwhals.

Thronderlag was the gathering place of the Throndar, the legendary progenitors of the Nordic realm. Here, overlooking the sea, the clans would assemble on the cold spring equinox to resolve their disputes, choose a target for summertime raiding, and elect a warleader. Today the Nord king takes counsel mainly with a select group of his jarls in his hall, and such great assemblies are no longer held, but Thonderlag remains the symbolic center of the Nordvyg.

Ruvenbrek sits in the far northeast of the lands settled by the Nords. Rich deposits of iron ore in the soil here, their wealth visible from rust-brown streaks on hillsides or in the waters of bogs, have drawn migrants to this otherwise remote and forbidding region.

Ykerslund is one of the northernmost districts of the Nordic kingdom. Its first inhabitants settled around a grove sacred to a wilderness goddess, eventually sowing extensive fields of barley and wheat.

Oristocorys sits on the Bay of Ortysia, part of the seaway between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea. Boats set forth into the narrow waters each day to catch tuna, swordfish and other large species migrating through the straits.

Gretysfjord is perhaps the oldest walled town in the Nordvyg, yet there are greybeards here who claim their grandsires were among the first to settle here permanently. At first it was but a seasonal market by the shore, drawing in traders from across the seas, until a local chief built walls and a great hall and began calling himself jarl. It is still the most frequented port on the Nordvyg, a welcome refuge to sailors from the unpredictable and cold northern seas.

Mot lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills known for the blaze of poppies that cover its slopes in the spring. The warm lands of the Vlandian south are well-suited to the growing of olives.

Ulikshorn lies beneath a basalt spire, visible for leagues around. Standing at its base on a clear day, one can see as far as the the eastern reaches of the Byalic and make out scores of fishing boats, spreading their nets to catch the huge schools of herring that frequent the offshore banks.

Thralathorp was settled by fugitives and runaways from various estates on the war-torn marches that divide the Sturgian and Nordic lands. In past generations its inhabitants made their living by signing on to dangerous, freezing whaling ventures organized by Byalic Sea merchants. Rrecently they have begun to organize their own voyages, bringing home wealth to what was once a poor and desperate corner of the north.

Holarsver was a landing point for hunters returning from seasonal voyages to the north with their hauls of walrus ivory. It has since grown into a thriving village and a center of trade on the Nordvyg coast.

Khimli sits in a basin in the Devseg plateau. Though this land is dry most of the year, it experiences winter snowfalls and muddy springs. Fine clay can be collected from the pools left by the snowmelt and the rains.

Arromanc lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills. The warm lands of the Vlandian south, where the air smells of sage, lavender and thyme, are well-suited to the growing of olives.

Vorfjall lies on the hills east of the Jumne, known for the bloom of purple lupin that fill the highland meadows in the late spring. The region also produces an abundant crop of wheat and is one of the breadbaskets of the eastern Nordvyg.
Elvania sits on the Bay of Ortysia, part of the seaway between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea. Hot southern afternoons and sea-cooled mornings make this good country for wine grapes.

Midskag is named after the cape that lies roughly in the middle of the coastal Nordvyg route through the Byalic. The villagers of the region near Midskag make their living from the sea, harvesting cod and ice-char from nearby banks.

The village of Nogrent is one of a series of settlements on the Biscan coast known for its seafaring population. Whales are the most dangerous quarry but also the must lucrative, and the boldest sailors here sometimes set out for months-long voyages that take them to Beinland, the Nordvyg and beyond.

Kargrev was once Car Gryff, the ringfort of the Battanian chief Gryff, but was conquered by the Sturgians two generations ago. Recently, the most intrepid of the villagers have joined Nords and others who go every summer to the far north, to Beinland and beyond, in search of walrus ivory.
Agilting Castle
Tharklif Castle
Ykerslund Castle
Brunmark Castle
Fimbulgard Castle
Haugr Castle
Hakarshus Castle
Skarthness Castle
Ulikshorn Castle
Avalyps sits near the headwaters of the River Calsa in the warm coastal hills of the southern Empire. The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.
Talivel lies in the middle of the Trand valley in the Vlandian heartland. Villagers plant olives here on the hillsides.

Haugr sits on the west branch of the Jumne river, where it meanders over its floodplain. It was named after a stone cairn on a riverside bluff, said by locals to have been built by forest-trolls. The region produces fine, dark clays, much prized by local potters.
Calioc sits on a flat plain between the Epiric and Biscan hills of the central Vlandian lands. The people of this district grow flax on the marshy lands.

Gauksdal sits on the middle reaches of the Jumne, the river that the Khuzaits call the Karakaz. This stretch of valley is named in commemoration of Gauk, a local homesteader, who escaped a Khuzait ambush by swimming across the river in spring when it was choked with floating ice. In the warmer months, villagers lay traps in the weedy shallows to catch pike and perch.

Galend overlooks the wave-beaten Biscan coast. It takes in the catch from the Biscan's intrepid fishermen and whalers who venture out far into the western ocean, as well as the wool of sheep from the green fog-covered hills. The current line of Vlandian kings comes from the clans who settled in this region during Osric Iron-Arm's invasion.
Omrotok sits at the foot of the Sulun Dag mountains, which mark the eastern border of the Devseg plateau. Villagers go to the nearby woods to harvest one of the Devseg's few sources of timber.

Gripsby, on the west coast of Beinland, was founded early in the island's settlement by mainlanders who hunted walrus on nearby beaches. These days they must venture farther afield, to the north of Beinland and the frozen seas beyond, but they still take a rich haul of valuable ivory.

Karahalli lies in the far north of the Khuzait confederacy, in borderlands contested by Sturgians and Nords. Though the winters are cold, the spring grasses are fine grazing for the local sheep, whose thick wool protects them from the region's piercing winds.

The fishing village of Aalgrun is known for the eels that thrive in the offshore shallows. Slightly further out to sea fishermen also find herring, as well as char that migrates to the sea from nearby streams to spawn.
Ormanfard sits by a small, fast-flowing river that runs down from the mountains of the Rhennod to fill the lake known as Ocspool. Rains are plentiful and wheat and barley grow well on the hillsides.

Faergap lies beside the Jumne river as it cuts through the hills known as the Iltanhindrun, named because they posed a barrier to mountain tribes just across the frontiers. Those peoples were pushed farther south and absorbed into the Khuzait confederacy, leaving a considerable land trafficked only by nomadic herdsmen and raiders. The region is rich in wheat, barley and other grains.

Balgard, which sits on the icy waters of the Byalic Sea, was founded by migrants from the Nordvyg. Legend holds that the initial wave of Nords arrogantly demanded tribute from the nearby Vakken and Sturgian tribes, who formed an alliance and drove the newcomers back to their ships. But the victors fell out over the spoils, until a canny Nord, Gundar, landed and volunteered to help them fairly divvy up the weapons and armor of his dead kinsmen. The residents recognized Gundar's lordship over the region and his descendants, intermarried with the Sturgians, are today the grand princes of Sturgia.

The village of Draugmyr takes its name from a nearby bog that was once a place of sacrifice. Though long since drained to create farmland, its rich wheatfields still turn up the odd bone or golden grave-offering.

Marathea lies on a narrow shelf of land between the Miron river and Mount Aracathos, the tallest peak in the Dryatic mountains. The villagers are skilled miners, and the red streaks running down the nearby cliffsides are evidence of rich iron ores.

Nordic tribes pushing into the dark forests to their east founded the citadel of Hargard several generations ago. It overlooks the river that the Nords call the Jumne, probably a derivation of a Sturgian term for the mysterious burial pits found along its banks. Today, the river forms the main artery of transportation for the Nord kingdom's eastern domains, a meeting-place of Nords, Vanni, Sturgians, and even some forest-dwelling cousins of the steppe tribes, all harvesting the wealth of the river-valley to sell to the peoples of the south.

Hvalvik is the main port on the remote northern island known to the Nords as Beinland, the land of bones. It is debated whether the island's namesake comes from the walrus ivory that drew hunters here, or the only trace that many left behind, buried in shallow graves alongside its bleak gravel-covered shores. In the last few generations, however, a run of milder winters and a growing mainland population has encouraged colonists to seek their fortune in Beinland, and the former cluster of whalers' huts known as Hvalvik is now a thriving town.

Montos sits at the base of the Cursion escarpment, near the Battanian frontier. The farmers here keep a watchful eye when tending their hillside fields, always looking for raiding parties coming westward from the valley of the Miron river to their east.
